titleStmt.title: To their Excellencies the Lords Justices of Ireland──────
The Humble Petition of Francis Harris,

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: Humbly Sheweth
That I went to warm my self in Lady Betty's Chamber, because I was cold,
And I had in my Purse, 7, 4, 6 besides farthings, in Mony, & Gold;
So, because I had been buying things for my Lady, last night,
I was resolv'd to tell my Mony, to see if it was right.
Now you must know, because my Trunk has a very bad lock,
Therefore all ye Mony, I have, wch, God knows, is a very small stock,
I keep in a pocket, tyd about my Middle, next my Smock.
So when I went to put up my purse, as God would have it, my smock was unript.
And, instead of putting it into my Pocket, down it slipt:
Then ye Bell rung, & I went down to put my Lady to bed,
And, God knows, I thought my Mony as safe as my Maidenhead.
So when I came up again, I found my Pocket feel very light,
But when I searc'd, & miss'd my Purse, Lord! I thought I shoud have sunk dowright
Lord! Madam, said Mary, how d'ye do? Indeed, says I, never worse;
But, pray Mary, can you tell me what I've done with my Purse?
Lord help me! said Mary, I never stir'd out of this place!
Nay, said I. I had it in Lady Betty's Chamber, that's a plain Case.
So Mary got me to bed, & cover'd me up warm,
However, she stole away my Garters, that I might do my self no harm:
So I tumbled, & toss'd all night, as you may very well think,
But hardly ever set my Eyes together, or slept a wink.
So I was a·Dream'd, methought, we went, & search'd ye Folk round,
And in a Corner of Mrs Dukes box, tyd up in a ragg, ye Mony was found.
So next Morning we told Whittle, & he fell a swearing;
Then my Dame Wadgar came, & she, you know, is thick of hearing;
Dame, said I, as loud as I could bawl, do you know what a loss Ive had?
Nay, said she. My Lord Collways Folks are all very sad,
For My Lord Dromedary comes a Tuesday without fail;
Pugh! said I, but yt is not ye thing I ail
Says Cary, says he, I have been a servant, this 25 years, come spring,
And, in all ye places I liv'd in, I never heard of such a thing.
Yes, said ye Steward, I remember when J was at my Lady Shrewsburies
Such a thing as this happen'd, just about ye time of Goosberries.
So I went to ye Party suspected, & found her full of Greif;
(Now, you must know, of all things in ye World, I hate a Theif.
However, I was resolv'd to bring ye Matter slyly about,)
Mrs Dukes, said I, heres an ugly accident happen'd out;
Tis not that I value ye Mony 3 skips of a louse,
But, ye thing I stand upon, is ye Credit of ye House;
Tis true, 7£, 4s, 6d, makes a great hole, in my wages,
Besides, as they say, service has no Inheritance in these ages.
Now, Mrs Dukes, you know, & every body understands,
That thô tis hard to judge, yet mony cant go with out hands.
The Devill take me, said she, (Blessing her self) if I ever saw it!
So she roar'd like a Bedlam, as tho I had calld her all to nought;
So, you know, what cou'd I say to her more,
I e'en left her, & came away as wise as I was before.
Well! but then they woud have me go to ye Cunning Man,
No, said I, tis ye same thing, ye Chaplain will be here anon.
So ye Chaplain came in; now ye Servants say, he is my Sweetheart,
Because he's always in my Chamber, & J always take his part.
So, befas ye Devill wou'd have it, before J was aware, out I blunderd;
Parson, said I, can you Cast a Nativity when a body's plunderd.
(Now, you must know, he hates to be calld Parson, like ye Devill)
Truly, says he, Mr Nabb, it might become you, to be more Civill:
If yor Mony be gone, as a Learn'd Divine says, D'ye see,
You are no Text for my handling, so take that from me:
I was never taken for a Conjuror before, I'de have you to know
Lord! said I, dont be angry, Ime sure I never thought you so;
You know, I honour ye Cloth, I design to be a Parson's wife,
I never took one in yor Coat for a Conjurer in all my life.
With that, he twisted his Girdle at me, like a rope, as who shou'd say,
Now you may go hang yor self for me, & so went away.
Well: I thought I shou'd have swooned; Lord! said I, what shall I do,
I have lost my Mony, & shall loose my true love too.
Then my Lord Calld me; Harry, said my Lord, Dont cry,
Ile give something towards thy loss, & says my Lady, so will I.
Oh! but said I, what if after all yeChaplain wont come too;
For that, he said, (ant please yor
Excellencies I must petition you.
The Premises tenderly Consider'd, I desire yor
Excellencies protection;
And that I may have a share in next sundays Collection:
And over & above, yt I may have yor Excellencies Letter;
With an Order for ye Chaplain aforesaid, or instead of him a better:
And then yor Petitioner, both Night & Day,
Or ye Chaplain, (for tis his trade) as in Duty bound,
Shall ever Pray &c──── 069-600B
